Pohnpei	Pohnpei is a high island in Micronesia. It is famous for its enormous megalithic structures, which were formerly religious sites. The most impressive of these had, however, been abandoned by the time the islanders came into regular contact with Europeans. Pohnpei is believed to mean 'upon a stone altar', a reference to the myth that the founding settlers had built up the island, with the help of the gods, from an enormous altar.	pohn1238	1853	dobbin2011[70-103]	2	dobbin2011[70-103]	2	dobbin2011[70-103]	2	dobbin2011[77]	1	dobbin2011[70-103]	1	dobbin2011[70-103]	1	dobbin2011[92]	0		0	hanlon1988[4]	0	dobbin2011[79-80]	0	dobbin2011[79-80]	1	hanlon1988[4-6]; dobbin2011[70-103]	1	dobbin2011[78]	1	riesenberg-1968[58]	1	riesenberg-1968[59]	1	riesenberg-1968[60]	1	keesing1984; petersen1990[40]; blust2007	1	keesing1984	0	keesing1984; blust2007	1	keesing1984; petersen1990[40]	1	keesing1984	0	bellwood_1995[109]	1	dobbin2011[70-103, 81]	0	cribb2000[2.21]	1	dobbin2011[81]	0	cribb2000[2.23]	156.7	ethnologue-map-micronesia-2014; daft-logic-distance-calculator2014	2603	hanlon1991[267]	158.2	hanlon1991[267]; google-mapsnone	6.9	hanlon1991[267]; google-mapsnone	1	hanlon1991[267]	2	hanlon1991[267]	778	hanlon1991[267]	336.7	hanlon1991[267]	1	dobbin2011[79]	0	riesenberg-1968[60-62]; dobbin2011[70-103]	1	dobbin2011[70-103]	3	hanlon1988[80-93]	2	christian1899[74]; hanlon1984[41]	0	christian1899[74, 122-124]	2	hanlon1988[40-41]	1	christian1899[74]	1	christian1899[74, 123]	10000	hanlon1991[267]	3	hanlon1988[39]	1	hanlon1988[39]	3	hanlon1991[268-269]	3	hanlon1991[269]	1	hanlon1991[269]	3	hanlon1984[267]; hanlon1988[39]	2		2	hanlon1988[44]	3	hanlon1988[3-86]			2	christian1899[73]	2	christian1899[125]	2	murrill1948[155]			3	christian1899[73]; murrill1948[155]	3	christian1899[73]	2	christian1899[73, 126-127]	3	christian1899[73, 126-127]	2	hanlon1991[268]	3	hezel1982[142-158, 143, 156]	0	hanlon1984	3	hanlon1991[269]; machiko2002[90]	2	hanlon1984[41]			3	hanlon1988[206]			3	foster-hezel2020	2	petersen1990[7]	2	foster-hezel2020	1	hanlon1991[268]; foster-hezel2020	2	foster-hezel2020	2	pohnpei2016	1	foster-hezel2020	3	petersen1990[7]	2	petersen1990[7]; hanlon1988[144-145, 206]	2014						1	foster-hezel2020

Varisi	Choiseul (Lauru) is a large island in the western Solomons. Varisi is one of the (according to Ethnologue) four languages spoken here. Scheffler's ethnography of Choiseul Island 'pertains only to the Varisi area', but given the cultural uniformity of Choiseul, 'it is probably valid in general terms for the island as a whole' (Scheffler, 1965, p. v)	vari1239	1900	scheffler1965[v]	2	scheffler1965[242-245]	2	scheffler1965[242-245]	2	scheffler1965[246-248, 250-251]	2	scheffler1965[246-248]	1	scheffler1965[240-253, 246-247]	1	scheffler1965[242-243]	0	scheffler1965[9, 240-253]	0	scheffler1965[9]	1	scheffler1965[247]	0	scheffler1965[247-248]	1	scheffler1965[240-253, 241]	1	scheffler1965[251]	1	scheffler1965[183-184]	1	scheffler1965[78, 82]	0	scheffler1965[4-5, 240-253]	1	scheffler1965[242-243, 250-251]	1	scheffler1965[242-243]	3	scheffler1965[179-180, 250-251]	1	scheffler1965[242-243]	1	scheffler1965[242-243]	2	bellwood_1995[109]	1	scheffler1965[14-24]	0	cribb2000[Map 2.21]	1	scheffler1965	0	cribb2000[Map 2.21]	0	scheffler1965[8]	1520	scheffler1965[8]	156.7	scheffler1965[8]	-6.8	scheffler1965[8]; Aeta	'Aeta' is one of the ethonyms given to the Negritos living in the Zambales mountains of western Luzon. The many Negrito groups of the Philippines share a distinctive phenotype that sets them apart from the majority of other Filipinos. Although many Negrito groups have historically been hunter-gatherers, the Aeta have a long history of farming.	boto1242	1903	reed1904[9]			2	reed1904[65-67]			2	reed1904[48, 65]			1	reed1904[65]											1	reed1904[63-64]									0	blevins2008			0	blevins2008	0	blevins2008	2	bellwood_1995[109]	1		0	cribb2000[Map 2.21]	1	reed1904[44]	0	cribb2000[Map 2.23]	0	reed1904[Plate II]	902	reed1904[Plate II]	120.4	reed1904[Plate II]	15.3	reed1904[Plate II]	1	reed1904[Plate II]							1	reed1904[65]							0	reed1904[33-37]	0	reed1904[33-37]	0	reed1904[36-37]	1	reed1904[36-37]	1	reed1904[36-38]	6000	reed1904[30-32]					3	reed1904[60]					2	reed1904[30-31, 70]	4	reed1904[63]	1	reed1904[70]	1	reed1904[68-71]	0	reed1904[43-44]	0	reed1904[39-48]	1	reed1904[44-48]	3	reed1904[40-41]	3	reed1904[44-48]	3	reed1904[41, 42]	0	reed1904[39-48]	1	reed1904[48]	2	reed1904[48]	1	reed1904[43-44]																																								
Ajie	The indigenous people of New Caledonia lacked an ethnonym for themselves prior to European contact. They are known today as Canaques or Kanaks, an exonym derived from the Hawaiian 'kanaka'. Although they speak over 30 languages, the Kanak people share a similar culture. The Ajie-speaking Kanaks of the Houailou Valley were described in detail by the French missionary / ethnographer Maurice Leenhardt, who oversaw their conversion to Christianity in the early twentieth century.	ajie1238	1902	clifford1982[1]; Alune	The Alune are a language community living in western Seram. Like many peoples of the Central Maluku area, they traced their origins to the mythical 'Nunusaku' tree.	alun1238	1917	boulan-smit-1998[1, 40, 65-66]													0	boulan-smit-1998[106-107]	1	boulan-smit-1998[106-107]	1	boulan-smit-1998[259]					1	boulan-smit-1998[116, 351]			1	boulan-smit-1998[226]													2	bellwood_1995[109]	1	boulan-smit-1998[29]	1	cribb2000[Map 2.21]	1	boulan-smit-1998[29, 73]	1	boulan-smit-1998[29]	0	boulan-smit-1998[2]	946	collins-1983[35]; daft-logic-distance-calculator2014	128.5	boulan-smit-1998[Map 1.2]	-3.1	boulan-smit-1998[Map 1.2]	1	boulan-smit-1998	4	boulan-smit-1998[7]	3027	boulan-smit-1998[8]	17746	boulan-smit-1998[7]	1	boulan-smit-1998[259]	1	boulan-smit-1998[46-47]	2	boulan-smit-1998[138-149]															2	boulan-smit-1998[vi, 87]	3	boulan-smit-1998[vi, 4]							2	boulan-smit-1998[40, 72, 83, 170, 284]			2	boulan-smit-1998[29-30, 44-45]	2	boulan-smit-1998[29-69]			0	boulan-smit-1998[13-19]	2	boulan-smit-1998[13-19]	3	boulan-smit-1998[13-119]	4	boulan-smit-1998[13-19]	3	boulan-smit-1998[13-19]	1	boulan-smit-1998[18-19]	2	boulan-smit-1998[13-19]	1	boulan-smit-1998[13-19]	0	boulan-smit-1998[13-19]	3	boulan-smit-1998[65-66]	1	boulan-smit-1998[65-66]	3	boulan-smit-1998[8]	1	boulan-smit-1998[65-66]	0	boulan-smit-1998[65-66]					3	boulan-smit-1998[66]	2	boulan-smit-1998[40]											3	boulan-smit-1998[40]	2	boulan-smit-1998[40]								
Ami	The Ami or Amis are the largest Taiwanese aboriginal ethnic group. Their homeland is in the east of the island, between the Taitung rift valley and the Pacific Ocean. Unlike most other Taiwanese aborigines, the Ami have a myth describing their migration from overseas.	amis1246	1899	lebar1975[117]; chen-coe1954; er-wei1974	2	chen-coe1954; er-wei1974	2	chen-coe1954; er-wei1974	2	chen-coe1954	1	chen-coe1954; er-wei1974	1	chen-coe1954; er-wei1974	1	er-wei1974	0	chen-coe1954; er-wei1974	0	chen-coe1954; er-wei1974	0	er-wei1974	2	er-wei1974	0	chen-coe1954; er-wei1974	1	er-wei1974	0	chen-coe1954; er-wei1974	1	mabuchi1971					0	blust2007; blevins2008; keesing1984			0	blust2007; blevins2008; keesing1984	0	blust2007; blevins2008; keesing1984	2	bellwood_1995[109]	1		1	cribb2000[2.21]	1	lebar1975[117]	1	cribb2000[2.23]	0	lebar1975[116]	306.7	blundell2000[44, 182]; daft-logic-distance-calculator2014	121.4	lebar1975[117]; google-mapsnone	23.4	lebar1975[117]; google-mapsnone	1	lebar1975[116]	4	copper2021	3952	ding-et-al2005[300]	32260	ding-et-al2005[300]			1	lebar1975[121]	2	lebar1975[120-121]; chen-coe1954	2	lebar1975[120-121]; chen-coe1954											30000	alvarez-1927	3	lebar1975[119]	1	lebar1975[119]	1	lebar1975[119]	1	lebar1975[119]			3	lebar1975[118, 120]; mabuchi1971[133]	2	lebar1975[121]	1	lebar1975[121]; mabuchi1971[133]	1	lebar1975[121]			1	lebar1975[118]	0	lebar1975[118]	0	lebar1975[118]	2	lebar1975[118]	4	lebar1975[118]	0	lebar1975[118]	2	lebar1975[118]	2	lebar1975[118]	0	lebar1975[118-119]	3	shiun-wey2003[262-364]	0	shiun-wey2003[262-266]	3	lebar1975[117]; shiun-wey2003[260]	2	shiun-wey2003[263-264]							3	copper2021	2	lebar1975[117]			2		2	copper2021	2	copper2021	1	copper2021	3	lebar1975[117]			2014		2	shiun-wey2003[265-266]			1	shiun-wey2003[277]
Aneityum	Aneityum is the southernmost island of Vanuatu. While many of Vanuatu's islands are linguistically diverse, the people of Aneityum constitute a single ethnolingustic group. Among other things, Aneityum is notable for having suffered one of the worst cases of depopulation in the Pacific following European contact.	anei1239	1848	spriggs-1981[21]	2	patterson-1882[128-129]	0	patterson-1882[27-32]	2	spriggs-1981[58, 6.11]	0	patterson-1882[27-32]; spriggs-1981[6.11]			1	spriggs-1981[3.5]					1	patterson-1882[131-132]	2	patterson-1882[131-132]			1	patterson-1882[130]	1	spriggs-1981[59-60]			1	spriggs-1981[60]											0	bellwood_1995[109]			0	cribb2000[Map 2.21]	1	spriggs-1985	0	cribb2000[Map 2.23]	63.7	spriggs-1981[11]; daft-logic-distance-calculator2014	1808	spriggs-1981[11]; daft-logic-distance-calculator2014	169.8	spriggs-1981[11]	-20.2	spriggs-1981[11]	1	spriggs-1981[11]	2	spriggs-1981[11]	852	spriggs-1981[12]	160	spriggs-1981[12]	1	spriggs-1981[59]	0	spriggs-1981	1	spriggs-1981[59-60, 64-65, 6.2]	3	spriggs-1981[55, 58-60]											4000	spriggs-1981[70-92]			3	spriggs-1981[58]	2	spriggs-1981[59]					2	spriggs-1981[57, 90]			3	spriggs-1981[63-64]	4	spriggs-1981[55-66]; spriggs-1985	0	spriggs-1981[31]	1	spriggs-1981[19, 3.2]	1	spriggs-1981[19-20, 3.2]	4	spriggs-1981[3.2]	1	spriggs-1981[19-20, 3.2]	4	spriggs-1981[86, 3.2]	2	spriggs-1981[20, 3.2]	2	spriggs-1981[20, 3.2, 3.3]	2	spriggs-1981[20, 3.2]	0	spriggs-1981[3.9]	5	spriggs-1981[63, 6.2]	0	spriggs-1985	3	spriggs-1985	2	spriggs-1985	0	spriggs-1985											2	spriggs-1981[31-32]											2014							
Anuta	Anuta is one of the islands traditionally known as the 'Polynesian Outliers'. Now politically part of the Solomon Islands, it is noteworthy for being one of the smallest inhabited islands in the Pacific. Arosi	The Arosi are an linguistic group occupying the western end of Makira (also known as San Cristobal) in the Solomon Islands. They were they subject of an ethnography by Fox (1924) who claimed that prior to Christianisation they had worshipped a supreme being, which is highly usual in this part of the world. Subsequent ethnographic work has cast considerable doubt upon this claim.	aros1241	1850	scott2007[xxix]; fox1924	0	fox1924[78-137, 201-280]; scott2007[161-200]	2	fox1924[124]; scott2007[315-316]	0	fox1924[78-137, 201-280]; scott2007	3	scott2007[172]	1	fox1924[78-137, 201-280]	1	scott2007[152-153]	0	scott2007[5]	0	scott2007[5, 13, 261-300]; fox1924[238]	1	scott2007[172-179]			2	scott2007[174-175, 188, 194, 265-266]	1	fox1924[262]	1	fox1924[297]	1	scott2007[157]	1	fox1924[297]			0	blust2007[418]			0	blust2007[418]	1	blust2007[418]	2	bellwood_1995[109]	1	scott2007[261-300]	0	cribb2000[Map 2.21]	1	fox1924[305]	0	cribb2000[Map 2.23]	0	fox1924[4]	1734	fox1924[4]; daft-logic-distance-calculator2014	161.3	scott2007[41]	-10.3	scott2007[41]	1	scott2007[37]	2	petterson-et-al2009	1250	clarke-bedford[64]	3191	clarke-bedford[64]	1	fox1924[112-114]	0	fox1924[78-137, 201-280, 305-313]	2	fox1924[116]	3	scott2007[75-82, 315-316]					2	fox1924[184, 190]	2	fox1924[184, 190]	2	fox1924[184, 190]			3	scott2007[6, 22]	1	scott2007[6, 22]	3	hays-1991D[289]	3	hays-1991D[289]			3	fox1924[8, 305]	3	scott2007[78]	1	fox1924[305]	1	fox1924[305]	0	bellwood-et-al-1975	2	hays1991A[289]	2	hays1991A[289]	3	scott2007[61]; hays1991A[289]	2	hays1991A[289]	4	scott2007[44-46]; hays1991A[289]	2	hays1991A[289]	2	hays1991A[289]	2	hays1991A[289]	1	hays1991A[289]			0	scott2007[95-100]	3	scott2007[xxix, 17]	2	scott2007[xxix]	1	scott2007[84, 105-129, 115-116]	0	scott2007[xxx, 37-39]	2	scott2007[37]	3	scott2007[56]	2	scott2007[xxix, 86-87]	2	scott2007[57]	1	scott2007[57, 62]	1	scott2007[39]			0	national-geospatial-intelligence-agency2009[180]; scott2007[62]	3	scott2007[82-103, 86-87]	1	scott2007[82-103]	2014	scott2007	2	scott2007[167-168]	2	scott2007[182-183, 186]	1	scott2007[xxix, 39, 301]

Atoni	The Atoni occupy large parts of Western Timor as well as the East Timorese enclade of Oecussi. Atoni lived inland and were historically noted for their aversion to the sea. Belep	The Belep Islands are located to the north of Grande Terre, the main island of New Caledonia. The Scottish anthropologist James Frazer provided an account of their religion (based on the work of the French missionary Lambert) in his popular book on ancestor worship 'The Belief in Immortality and the Worship of the Dead'.	nyal1254	1856	frazer1913[325]	2	lambert1900[19-20, 41-42]	0		2	lambert1900[28, 44]	3	lambert1900[24, 44]; dubois1985[15]; frazer1913[338]	0		1	douglas1998[271]	0				0	lambert1900[13, 235-244]	0	lambert1900[13, 235-344]	0		1	frazer1913[332]; lambert1900[27]	1	rozier1990[79]	1	lambert1900[113-114]					0	blevins2008; blust2007; keesing1984			0	blevins2008; blust2007; keesing1984	0	blevins2008; blust2007; keesing1984	0	bellwood_1995[109]	1		0	cribb2000[Map 2.21]	1	douglas1970[190]	0	cribb2000[Map 2.23]	30.8	ethnologue-map-of-new-caledonia2014; daft-logic-distance-calculator2014; lambert1900[81]	1260	daft-logic-distance-calculator2014	163.6	frazer1913[325]; google-mapsnone	-19.7	frazer1913[325]; google-mapsnone	2	lambert1900[81]	4	murienne-et-al2005[2]	283	dubois1985[7]	55.6	dubois1985[7]	1	lambert1900[26, 44, 75]; frazer1913[327]	0	lambert1900					2	lambert1900[107-108]	0	lambert1900[104-111, 147-148]	1	lambert1900[104-111, 147-148]	1	rozier1990[78]; lambert1900[104-111, 147-148]	1	lambert1900[104-111, 148]; rozier1990[78]	700	dubois1985[9]											2	dubois1985[9]; lambert1900[81]			4	dubois1985[17]; douglas1970[190]	1	dubois1985[17]; douglas1970	0	bellwood-et-al-1975	0	lambert1900[204]; rozier1990[77]	0	lambert1900	0	lambert1900[204-215]	0	lambert1900[204]	4	rozier1990[77]; lambert1900[204]; frazer1913[339]	2	lambert1900[204]	3	lambert1900[205-211]	3	lambert1900[205-211]	0	lambert1900[204-215]					3		2	frazer1913[325]					2	eberhard2020	3	central-intelligence-agency-new-caledonia2013	2												3		1		2014						1	
Bellona	Bellona, a raised coral island, is one of the 'Polynesian Outliers'. Its language and culture are very similar to those of neighbouring Rennell. Berawan	The Berawan mainly inhabit four longhouse communities on the Lower Baram River. While they have historically been considered a subgroup of the neighbouring Kenyah, they are culturally and linguistically distinctive. A notable feature of Berawan culture, as described by Metcalf (1982, 1989), is their elaborate secondary treatment of the dead.		1950	metcalf1987[250-251]	2	metcalf1982[47, 244, 248]	2	metcalf1982[247, 248]	2	metcalf1982[23, 248]	2	metcalf1982[50, 244, 248]; Besemah	The Besemah people inhabit the southern highlands of Sumatra. Like many of their neighbours, they speak 'Central' or 'Middle Malay', and are now Muslim. Traditionally the nearby volcano Gunung Dempo was sacred to the Besemah people, and was believed to be inhabited by various supernatural agents, including the spirits of their dead.	cent2053	1818	raffles1835[337-384]; collins1979	2	raffles1835[382-383]	2	raffles1835[381-382]; collins1979[303]	2	raffles1835[382-383]; forbes1885[198-199]; collins1979[183, 188-189]	1	raffles1835[383-384]; forbes1885[198-199]; collins1979[1-345, 183, 188-189]	2	raffles1835[381-382]	1	raffles1835[382]; collins1979[29]	0	collins1979; forbes1885[194]	1	forbes1885[194]	1	collins1979[177, 210]	0	forbes1885[200-201]; collins1979[177]	2	forbes1885[201-203]; collins1979[27-29]	1	raffles1835[381-382]			1	collins1979[197]					0	blust2007; keesing1984; blevins2008			0	blust2007; keesing1984; blevins2008	0	blust2007; keesing1984; blevins2008	2	bellwood_1995[109]	1	collins1979[54]	2	raffles1835[349]; collins1979[54, 311]	1	collins1979[54, 64]	2	collins1979[54]; raffles1835[382]	0	collins1979[57-58]	583.1	daft-logic-distance-calculator2014; collins1979[iv]	103.3	collins1979[iv]; google-mapsnone	-4.1	collins1979[iv]; google-mapsnone	1	collins1979[57-58]	4	sunda-shelf2016	3800	sumatra2017	480793	sumatra2017	1				1	collins1979[179-200]	4	jaspan1972a[35]	2	raffles1835[379]									100000	jaspan1972a[35]; andaya-1993[230]	1	jaspan1972a[35]; bowen1993[198]	3	jaspan1972a[35]; bowen1993[198]			3	jaspan1972a[35]			4	collins1979[92]; andaya-1993[230]; jaspan-1964[35]	4	raffles1835[349]	3	jaspan1972a[35]	1	jaspan1972a[35]; collins1979[105]			1	raffles1835[377]			2	collins1979[302-306]			4	raffles1835[348, 350]; jaspan1972a[35]			1	collins1979[302-306, 325]	2	collins1979[302-306]	2				0	bowen1993[199]; jaspan1972a[35]	3	bowen1993[199]; jaspan1972a[35]	0	jaspan1972a[35]									2	bowen1993[197-198]			1	jaspan1972a[35]; bowen1993[198]	2	collins1979[275-276]			1	collins1979[63-64]	3	bowen1993[197-198]	2	bowen1993[197-198]; collins1979[110-111]	2014		2	collins1979[312]	1		2	bowen1993[199]
Biak	The people of the Biak Islands (off the northern coast of western New Guinea) speak one language, known as Biak, Numfor, or Biak-Numfor. Prior to European colonisation in the early 1900s, they were nominal vassals of the Tidore Sultanate. They are particularly well know for having being at the centre of the Koreri movement, a syncretic religion centering on the culture-hero Manarmakeri.	biak1248	1911	kamma1972[v]; rutherford2003[186, 319]	0	kamma1972[14-16]	2	kamma1972[14-15]	2	kamma1972[15-16]	2	kamma1972[15]	1	kamma1972[14-16]	1	van-baaren2010[52]	0	kamma1972[64-96]; Bontok	The Bontok (also known as Bontoc Igorots) live in and around the town of Bontoc in the Cordillera of Luzon, and speak several closely related languages. Historically they lived in large villages or towns (often called 'pueblos') and cultivated rice using a sophisticated system of terraces.	cent2292	1903	jenks1905[13]	2	jenks1905[201-204]	0	jenks1905[196-215]	0	jenks1905[196-215]	3	jenks1905[196-198]	1	jenks1905[196-215]	1	jenks1905[198]	0	jenks1905[196-226]	0	jenks1905[196-226]	1	jenks1905[215]	0	jenks1905[196-215]	2	jenks1905[200-204]	1	jenks1905[216]	0	jenks1905[48-79, 196-214]	0	jenks1905[48-79, 196-214]	0	jenks1905[81-166, 196-215]			0	blust2007; Bughotu	Bughotu is the name given to the southern tip of Santa Isabel Island, as well as the language spoken there. In the second half of the nineteenth century the people of Bugotu were both perpetrators and victims of large-scale headhunting raids.	bugh1239	1885	jackson1975	1	bogesi1948b	0	bogesi1948b	2	bogesi1948a	2	bogesi1948b	0	bogesi1948b	1	bogesi1948a					0	bogesi1948b	0	bogesi1948b			1	bogesi1948a			1	bogesi1948a	1	bogesi1948a			1	blust2007			0	blust2007; bogesi1948b	1	blust2007; bogesi1948b	2	bellwood_1995[109]	1	jackson1975[65, 59]	0	cribb2000[Map 2.21]	1	jackson1975[65]	0	cribb2000[Map 2.23]	0	bogesi1948a	1709	tryon-hackman-1983[23]; daft-logic-distance-calculator2014	159.8	tryon-hackman-1983[23]; google-mapsnone	-8.5	tryon-hackman-1983[23]; google-mapsnone	2	tryon-hackman-1983[23]	2	laracy-foster2020	1219	clarke-bedford[64]	4660	clarke-bedford[64]	0	bogesi1948b	1	bogesi1948a; bogesi1948b; jackson1975			3	bogesi1948b; bogesi1948a	0	bogesi1948b	0	bogesi1948b					1	bogesi1948a; bogesi1948b	4000	jackson1975	3	bogesi1948a[217]	1	bogesi1948a[217]											3	jackson1975	1	jackson1975	0	bellwood-et-al-1975	2	bogesi1948a[223-224]			3	bogesi1948a[223]			3	bogesi1948a[221, 223]			2	bogesi1948a[225-226]	1	bogesi1948a[223, 225-226]			1	jackson1975	0	jackson1975	3	jackson1975	2	jackson1975	0	jackson1975; bogesi1948a; bogesi1948b	1	solomon-islands-census-isabel-profile2009[25]	2	solomon-islands-census-isabel-profile2009[32]	3	solomon-islands-census-isabel-profile2009[28]					2	santa-isabel2016					1	santa-isabel2016					2014						1	jackson1975
Buka	Buka is an island separated by a narrow strait from the larger island of Bougainville to the south. The people of Buka and northern Bougainville speak related Austronesian languages, and are sometimes considered a  cultural unit. The primary source on this culture, Beatrice Blackwood's 'Both Sides of Buka Passage', is based largely on fieldwork carried out in the Tinputz-speaking village of Kurtatchi on the north coast of Bougainville.	solo1257	1929	blackwood-1935[7]	1	blackwood-1935[462-543, 505]	1	blackwood-1935[462-543, 505]	0	blackwood-1935[462-543]	2	blackwood-1935[477-478]	1	blackwood-1935[462-543, 524-525]	1	blackwood-1935[516-517]	0	blackwood-1935[37-40]	0	blackwood-1935[37-40]			1	blackwood-1935[505-506, 513]	1	blackwood-1935[462-543]	1	blackwood-1935[505]	0	blackwood-1935[32-81, 462-543]	1	blackwood-1935[64-65]	0	blackwood-1935[298-543]			0	blackwood-1935[475]			0	blackwood-1935[475]	0	blackwood-1935[475]	2	blackwood-1935[109]	1	ogan1991[131]	0	cribb2000[2.21]	1	blackwood-1935[xxii-xiii]	0	cribb2000[2.23]	0	blackwood-1935[xxii-xxiii]	1447	blackwood-1935[xxii]; Bukidnon	'Bukidnon' was originally an exonym meaning 'mountain people' in Cebuano, but it was subsequently adopted by one of the mountain peoples of Mindanao to refer to themselves. Until the late nineteenth century, when they were converted to Christianity, the Bukidnon worshipped a range of supernaturals including ancestral spirits, nature spirits, and a high god.	binu1244	1880	cole1956[14-16]	2	cole1956[89-117]	2	cole1956[89-98]	0	cole1956[89-98]	1	cole1956[91-92]	2	cole1956[89-98]	1	cole1956[92]	0	cole1956[89-98, 126-132]	2	cole1956[127]	1	cole1956[92]	1	cole1956[92]	0	cole1956[89-98, 126-132]	1	cole1956[97]	1	cole1956[89-90]	1	cole1956[71]	0	cole1956[45-67, 89-117]			0	blevins2008; blust2007; keesing1984			0	blevins2008; blust2007; keesing1984	0	blevins2008; blust2007; keesing1984	2	bellwood_1995[109]	2	cullon1968[18]; cole1956[126]	1	cribb2000[Map 2.21]	1	edgerton1993[52, 54]	1	cribb2000[Map 2.23]; cole1956[126]	0	cole1956[15]	1731	cole1956[15]; daft-logic-distance-calculator2014	125	cole1956[15]; google-mapsnone	8.2	cole1956[15]; google-mapsnone	1	cole1956[15]	4	yumul-et-al-2009[732-733]	2954	mindanao-2016	94630	mindanao-2016	0	cole1956[76, 89-98]	0	cole1956[84]	2	cole1956[79-80, 89-117]	2	cole1956[99-117]	0	cole1956[68, 72]	0	cole1956[33, 72]	0	cole1956[29]	0	cole1956[72]	1	cole1956[26, 72]	13000	cole1956[14]	2	edgerton1993[53]	2	edgerton1993[53]	3	cole1956[75]	5	edgerton1993[54]			2		4	cole1956[79-88]; edgerton1993[54]	1	edgerton1993[54]	1	cole1956[82]; edgerton1993[54]	1	cole1956[45]	2	cole1956[51, 56]	1	cole1956[45-48, 51, 56]	3	cole1956[45, 56]	1	cole1956[45-48, 51, 56]	3	cole1956[45, 56]	2	cole1956[45, 56]	1	cole1956[45, 48-51, 56]	1	cole1956[45, 48-51, 56]	1	cole1956[45]			0	cole1956[14]	3	edgerton1993[54-55]	2	edgerton1993[52]; cole1956[8]			3	edgerton1993[53]; lebar1975[39]	3	edgerton1993[52]	3	cairns1997[41]	2	edgerton1993[52-53, 54]	2		2	edgerton1993[53]; cairns1997[40-41]							3	edgerton1993[52-53, 54]	0	cole1956[16]	2014						1	
Bunun	The Bunun live in the mountains of central Taiwan. Traditional Bunun religion has been described as 'atheistic', a reference to the fact that it centred on impersonal supernatural forces rather than supernatural beings. They converted to Christianity from the 1960s onwards, but the version of Christianity that they practice is notably syncretic.	bunu1267	1894	huang-1993	2	huang1995[69-70]; ferrell1969[34]	2	huang1995[69-70]; Casiguran Dumagat	The Casiguran Dumagat are one of the many 'Negrito' groups of the Philippines. Negritos, literally 'little blacks', share a distinctive phenotype that differs from that of the majority of other Filipinos. The Casiguran Dumagat are one of the Negrito groups often known as 'Agta'.	casi1235	1936	headland1975	2	vanoverbergh1938A	2	vanoverbergh1938A; headland1975	0	vanoverbergh1938A; headland1975	1	vanoverbergh1938A; headland1975	0	vanoverbergh1938A; headland1975	0	vanoverbergh1938A; headland1975	0	vanoverbergh1938A	0	vanoverbergh1938A	0	vanoverbergh1938A	1	vanoverbergh1938A	0	vanoverbergh1938A	1	vanoverbergh1936	0	vanoverbergh1938A	1	vanoverbergh1938A	0	vanoverbergh1937; vanoverbergh1938A	0	blevins2008	0	blevins2008	3	blevins2008	1	blevins2008	0	blevins2008	2	bellwood_1995[109]	2	headland1975	0	cribb2000[2.21]	1	vanoverbergh1937	1	vanoverbergh1938A	0	headland1975	930	headland1975	122	headland1975	16.3	headland1975	1	headland1975	2	yumul-et-al-2009[732-733]	2930	luzon2019	104688	luzon2019	1	vanoverbergh1938A	0	vanoverbergh1937; vanoverbergh1938A	3	vanoverbergh1938A; headland1975	1	vanoverbergh1938A; headland1975	1	vanoverbergh1937	0	vanoverbergh1937	1	vanoverbergh1937	1	vanoverbergh1937	1	vanoverbergh1937	1600	headland1975; headland1997	2	headland1993[5]	2	headland1993[5]	1	headland1975			3	headland1993[5]	2	vanoverbergh1938A; headland1993[6]	4	vanoverbergh1937	4	vanoverbergh1938A	3	vanoverbergh1938A	0	vanoverbergh1937	0	vanoverbergh1937	3	vanoverbergh1937	2	vanoverbergh1937	1	vanoverbergh1937	1	vanoverbergh1937	3	vanoverbergh1937	1	vanoverbergh1937	3	vanoverbergh1937	4	vanoverbergh1937											3	headland1993[4]					2	vanoverbergh1938A	2	headland1993[5]	2	headland1993[5]							3	vanoverbergh1938A			2014							
Chamorro	The Chamorro are the indigenous people of the Marianas Islands. Originally they were divided into social classes, of which the name 'Chamorro' referred only to members of the highest. Spanish colonization was highly traumatic for the Chamorro and resulted in massive population decline.	cham1312	1668	thompson1945[3-5]	1	thompson1945[20-25]; cunningham1992[99]	0	thompson1945[20-23]; Cheke Holo	The Cheke Holo people inhabit the central portion of the island of Santa Isabel in the Solomon Islands. In pre-Christian times, they built megalithic shrines in honour of deceased chiefs. Between 1860 and 1899, they suffered greatly at the hands of raiders and headhunters from other parts of Santa Isabel and from other islands further to the west. As a result, most either fled to remote inland areas of the island or to Bughotu in the far south, where they came into contact with Anglican missionaries. Most converted to Christianity in the early twentieth century.	chek1238	1900	white1991[93-97]	0	white1991[30-51]	0	white1991[30-51]	3	white1991[30-51, 36-38, 54-55, 110, 249]	1	white1991[30-51, 36-38, 54-55, 110, 249]	2	white1991[30-51, 43, 108-109]	1	white1991[38, 54-55]					1	white1991[249]					1	white1991[38]	1	white1991[38, 60]			1	white1991[54-55]	0		0	blust2007; keesing1984; blevins2008; white1991[37-38]	0		0	blust2007; keesing1984; blevins2008; white1991[37-38]	0	blust2007; keesing1984; blevins2008; white1991[37-38]	2	bellwood_1995[109]	1	white1991[82-84, 93-94]	0	cribb2000[2.21]	1	white1991[83-84]	0	cribb2000[2.23]	0	white1991[23]	1702	tryon-hackman-1983[23]; google-mapsnone	159.6	tryon-hackman-1983[23]; google-mapsnone	-8.3	tryon-hackman-1983[23]; google-mapsnone	2	white1991[22-23]	2	laracy-foster2020	1219	clarke-bedford[64]	4660	clarke-bedford[64]	1	white1991[249]	0	white1991[36-37, 40]	1	white1991[54-55, 58-59]	2	white1991													3	white1991[33]	1	white1991[33]											1	white1991[82-83, 89]	1	white1991[89]	0	bellwood-et-al-1975	0	white1991[21-23]	2	white1991[21]	2	white1991[21]	2	white1991[21]	4	white1991[21-23]	1	white1991[21, 23, 89]	1	white1991[21, 23, 89]	1	white1991[21, 23, 89]	2	white1991[21-23, 33, 40]	1	white1991[95]	0	white1991[81-130]	3	white1991[95, 136]	1	white1991[81-130, 93]	1	white1991[81-130]; solomon-islands-census-isabel-profile2009	0	solomon-islands-census-isabel-profile2009[35]	2	solomon-islands-census-isabel-profile2009[32]	3	solomon-islands-census-isabel-profile2009[28, 30]	2	white1991[183-208]	2	solomon-islands-census-isabel-profile2009[39]	2	white1991[35, 254]; santa-isabel2016	0				1		2	white1991[183-208]	0	white1991[183-208]	2014						1	solomon-islands-census-isabel-profile2009
Chuuk	Chuuk (or 'Truk') is a complex atoll consisting of a ring of coral islets surrounding a cluster of volcanic high islands. Prior to the adoption of Christianity in the early twentieth century, the Chuukese worshipped a wide array of supernatural agents, including 'sky gods' and deified high chiefs.	chuu1238	1902	goodenough2002[xvi-xvii]	2	goodenough2002[83-122, 156-178, 192-209]	2	goodenough2002[83-122]	3	goodenough2002[134-178]	1	goodenough2002[134-178]	2	goodenough2002[114-118, 335]	1	goodenough2002[135]	0	goodenough2002[123-132]	1	goodenough2002[123-132]	1	goodenough2002[133-155]	0	goodenough2002[91, 133-155]	2	goodenough2002[88, 91-122, 156-320,]	1	goodenough2002[86]	1	goodenough2002[298]	1	goodenough2002[249]	1	goodenough2002[298-299]	1	goodenough2002[72-73]	1	goodenough2002[72-73]	3	goodenough2002[30-31, 72-73, 126]	1	goodenough2002[72-73]	1	goodenough2002[72-73]	0	bellwood_1995[109]	1	hezel1973; Dobuans	Dobu is a tiny island in the D'Entrecasteaux Archipelago, near the eastern tip of New Guinea. Dobuans are an ethnolinguistic group that is centred upon this island but occupies a much larger area. The anthropologist Reo Fortune provided a famously dark portrayal of Dobuan society in the classic ethnography 'Sorcerers of Dobu'.	dobu1241	1890	bromilow1929[77-94, 223]	1	bromilow1929[77-94]; fortune1932[94-102]	1	bromilow1929[77-94]; Eastern Sumbanese	Sumba is an island in Eastern Indonesia. The people of the eastern two-thirds of the island speak a single language and share a relatively homogeneous culture, while those in the west are more diverse. The indigenous religion of Eastern Sumba centres around beings called Marapu, the divine ancestors of the Sumbanese. Information on this culture is largely drawn from Forth's (1981) ethnography of the traditional Eastern Sumbanese domain of Rindi.	kamb1299	1905	forth1981[1-22]	2	forth1981[87-94]	1	forth1981[73-132]	2	forth1981[87-94]	2	forth1981[77-78, 92]	2	forth1981[73-132]	1	forth1981[88-89]	2	forth1981[90]	2	forth1981[83]	1	forth1981[171-213]	1	forth1981[171-213]	2	forth1981[89-94]	1	forth1981[101]	1	forth1981[220, 227]	1	forth1981[352, 356-357]	0	forth1981[14-17, 66-132]	0	blust2007; keesing1984; blevins2008	0	blust2007; keesing1984; blevins2008	0	blust2007; keesing1984; blevins2008	1	blevins2008	1	blevins2008	2	bellwood_1995[109]	1	forth1981[7]	1	forth1981[7, 76-77]	1	forth1981[7-8]	1	forth1981[7-8]	0	forth1981[3]	694	forth1981[4]; daft-logic-distance-calculator2014	120.3	forth1981[4]; google-mapsnone	-9.9	forth1981[4]; google-mapsnone	1	forth1981[3]	3	vel-2008[24]	1220	sumba2016	11153	forth1981[3]; sumba2016	1	forth1981[182]	1	hoskins1996[216-248]	2	forth1981[236-264]	3	forth1981[45-46, 254]	2	forth1981[159-163]	0	forth1981[155-170]	2	forth1981[163, 165]	0	forth1981[155-170, Plates 2b-6b]	1	forth1981[155-170, plate 2b]	60000	forth1981[13]; gooszen1999[225]	1	lebar1972[76]	3	lebar1972[76]	3	lebar1972[75-76]					3	lebar1972[74-75]; forth1981[14]	4	forth1981[214-281, 280]	1	lebar1972[74-77]; forth1981[7]	1	forth1981[7-8]	1	forth1981[16]	2	forth1981[15]	1	forth1981[16]	1	forth1981[14-17, 15]	1	forth1981[16]	4	forth1981[14]	3	forth1981[15-16]	3	forth1981[15-16]	3	forth1981[15-16]	2	forth1981[14-17]	2		1	keane2007[152-153]	3	keane2007[154]; vel2005[91]	2	forth1981[9]	0	keane2007	1		2		3		2	hoskins2000[612]; hoskins1996[239]; vel2005[83]	2	vel2005[82-83]	2	sumba2016	2		1	sumba2016	1	sumba2016	3	hoskins2000[612]; hoskins1996[239]; vel2005[83]	2	hoskins1996[217]; hoskins2000[612]	2014		2	keane2007[161, 205, 227, 229-230]	2	keane2007[107-109, 223-251]	1	vel2005[91]; keane2007[153]
Eastern Toraja	Eastern Toraja is the name given to the Bare'e (also known as Pamona) -speakers living in the interior of Sulawesi in Eastern Indonesia. Prior to their conversion to Christianity, the Eastern Toraja worshipped a pantheon of beings, including a high god who was believed to have created human beings using bellows.		1892	henley2005b[4, 7]	2	downs1956[12-27]	2	downs1956[12, 23]	2	downs1956[32]	3	downs1956[28-32]; Erromango	Erromango is a small, high island in the south of Vanuatu. The islanders adopted Presbyterian Christianity in the early twentieth century, after a decades-long process of missionisation during which several missionaries lost their lives. The deaths of these missionaries led to the island becoming popularly known as 'Martyrs' Island'.	urav1235	1860	crowley1997	1	robertson1902[389-404]; humphreys1926[165-167]	0	robertson1902[389-404]; humphreys1926[165-167]	0	robertson1902[389-404]; Fijians	The modern state of Fiji includes the Fiji Islands as well as the remote island of Rotuma. In keeping with how the earliest ethnographic sources use the term, we consider 'Fijians' to include all the indigenous peoples of the Fiji Islands, but not Rotumans, who have been coded separately.	west2519	1840	wilkes1845; Futuna	The island of Futuna, sometimes known as 'East Futuna' to distinguish it from another island of the same name, is in Western Polynesia. The island is known, among other things, for its connection to the martyr Pierre Chanel, whose murder in 1841 precipitated the conversion of the island to Christianity. Prior to this event, the islanders had worshipped Fakavelikele, a deified founding ancestor.	east2447	1837	burrows1936[17-20, 102]	1	burrows1936[112-113]; kirch1994b[261]	1	burrows1936[106, 107-108, 112-13]	3	burrows1936[112-113]; Futuna-Aniwa	Futuna and Aniwa are 'Polynesian Outliers' in southern Vanuatu, speaking dialects of the same language (Futuna-Aniwa). Ga'dang	The Gaddang are a collection of related ethnolinguistic groups in the eastern Cordillera of Luzon. While most Gaddang had converted to Christianity by 1900, a minority (around 10%) maintained their indigenous religion until the 1970s. This minority, formerly known as the 'Pagan Gaddang', was studied in detail by the ethnographer Ben Wallace in the 1960s. Since the conversion of these Gaddang to Christianity, the term 'Pagan Gaddang' has become defunct. Wallace (2013) now refers to this group as the Ga'dang, which reflects their local pronunciation of their ethonym.	gadd1244	1965	2013wallace[7-10]	1	2013wallace[92-104, 92, 97, 141-144]	0	2013wallace[92-97]	0	2013wallace[92-97]	1	2013wallace[92-97, 104]; lebar1975[102]	2	2013wallace[96-97]	0	2013wallace[92-97]	0	2013wallace[92-97, 141-144]	2	2013wallace[141-144]	1	2013wallace[93]	0	2013wallace[93]	2	2013wallace[92-104, 92, 141-144]					1	wallace1975[207-208]					0	blust2007; blevins2008; keesing1984			0	blust2007; blevins2008; keesing1984	0	blust2007; blevins2008; keesing1984	2	bellwood_1995[109]	2	2013wallace[9, 109]	0	2013wallace[8-10, 92-104]; cribb2000[Map 2.21]	1	2013wallace[27, 38-39]	0	2013wallace[8-10, 92-104]; cribb2000[2.23]	0	lebar1975[100]	812.3	2013wallace[12-13]	121.5	2013wallace[12-13]; google-mapsnone	17.2	2013wallace[12-13]; google-mapsnone	1	2013wallace[7-8]	2	yumul-et-al-2009[732-733]	2930	luzon2019	104688	luzon2019	1	2013wallace[91-115]	1	2013wallace[79-82]	3	lebar1975[102]; 2013wallace[96-97]	1	2013wallace[97-104]; lebar1975[102]	0	2013wallace[38-42, 97-104]	0	2013wallace[38-42, 97-104]	1	2013wallace[40, 97-104]	0	2013wallace[38-42]	1	2013wallace[40, 97-104]	2500	lebar1975[101]	1	lebar1972[101, 102]	1	lebar1972[101, 102]	1	wallace-1969[183]	5	lebar1975[101]	3	lebar1975[101-102]	1	lebar1975[101, 102]			3	2013wallace[80-81]; lebar1975[102]	3	2013wallace[80-81]; lebar1975[102]			1	lebar1975[101]	1	wallace1951[55-56]	1	2013wallace[55-56]	1	2013wallace[55-56]	4	lebar1975[101]; 2013wallace[54-56]	2	2013wallace[55-56]	2	2013wallace[55]	2	2013wallace[55-56]	3	lebar1975[101]; 2013wallace[55-56]	3	2013wallace[11-112]	0	2013wallace[112]	3	2013wallace[8]	1	2013wallace[111]	0	2013wallace[109-115, 110]			2	2013wallace[70]	3	2013wallace[70]	2	2013wallace[48-49, 82-83]	2	2013wallace[55-56, 60-62]	2	2013wallace[55-56]	2	2013wallace[48-49]					2	2013wallace[48-49, 82-83]	0	2013wallace[48-49, 82-83]	2014		2	2013wallace[8, 113]			1	2013wallace[8]
Goodenough Island	Goodenough is one of the islands making up the D'Entrecasteaux Archipelago off the eastern tip of New Guinea. Its people speak several closely related languages. The main source used when coding this culture was Jenness and Ballantyne's 'The Northern D'Entrecasteaux', which was based primarily on observations collected in the district of Bwaidoka in the island's southeast.	bwai1242	1911	jenness-ballantyne1920[11]	0	jenness-ballantyne1920[145-153]	0	jenness-ballantyne1920[145-153]	0	jenness-ballantyne1920[145-153]	1	jenness-ballantyne1920[120, 145-153]	0	jenness-ballantyne1920[145-153]	0	jenness-ballantyne1920[145-153]	0	jenness-ballantyne1920[154-162]	0	jenness-ballantyne1920[154-162]	1	jenness-ballantyne1920[120]	1	jenness-ballantyne1920[145-153]	0	jenness-ballantyne1920[154-162]	1	jenness-ballantyne1920[150]	0	jenness-ballantyne1920[63-89, 145-153]	1	jenness-ballantyne1920[117]	0	jenness-ballantyne1920[28-36, 145-153]			0	blust2007; Hawaiians	The Hawaiian Islands represent one of the most remote outposts of Polynesian culture. Pre-contact Hawaiian polities were highly complex, and have been labelled 'archaic states'. The Hawaiians worshipped many supernatural agents, of whom the principal deities were Kanaloa, Kane, Ku, and Lono.	hawa1245	1777	valeri1985[xvii-xxviii]	2	beckwith1970[11-49, 60-81]; valeri1985[12-13]	0	valeri1985[3-36, 9-10, 11-12, 31]	2	valeri1985[19-20]; Iban	The Iban are an ethnolinguistic group that now live primarily in Sarawak, but are believed to have migrated from the Upper Kapuas region of Kalimantan within the past few hundred years. In the nineteenth century they were notorious for headhunting and resistance to colonial control. The principal Iban god was Sengalang Bulong, who manifested himself in the form of a Brahminy Kite.	iban1264	1839	pringle1968[111-112]; jensen1974[55-59]; perham-1881	2	jensen1974[100-140]; perham-1881; Ifaluk	Ifaluk is part of the cultural and linguistic region of Micronesia known as Woleiai. Ifaluk has been of interest to ethnographers because its relative isolation meant that its indigenous religion was retained under after World War II, when the islanders began to convert to Christianity. Prior to the arrival of the colonial powers Spain, Germany and Japan in the area, Ifaluk and the other Woleiai islands were vassals of the chiefs of Yap.	wole1240	1947	burrows-spiro1953[2]	2	burrows-spiro1953[210, 227, 345]	1	burrows-spiro1953[207-243, 344-348]	0	burrows-spiro1953[137, 207-243, 344-348]	3	burrows-spiro1953[213-227]; Ifugao	The Ifugao are one of several large, historically non-Christian ethnic groups living in the mountains of northern Luzon. The Ifugao have been noted for worshipping a very large number of supernatural agents (over 1000, according to Barton, 1946). Since the 1960s, most Ifugao have converted to Christianity.		1851	alarcon-scott1965; villaverde-1909; barton1946; lambrecht-1932-1941; lambrecht1962	2	barton1946[11-12, 27-28]	2	barton1946[27-35, 38-39]	2	barton1946[27-28]	2	barton1946[100]	2	barton1946[27-35]	1	barton1946[59, 70]	0	barton1955	1	beyer1913[99-100]; barton1946[96-97]	1	villaverde-1909[247]	1	barton1946[247]	2	barton1946[11-12, 27-28, 35, 67]	1	villaverde-1909[247-248]	0	barton1919[11-14]	1	barton1919[12]	1	barton1919[12]			0	blevins2008[262]; blust2007; keesing1984			0	blevins2008[262]; blust2007; keesing1984	0	blevins2008[262]; blust2007; keesing1984	2	bellwood_1995[109]	1	dumia1979[38-39]	2	barton1946[13]	1	dumia1979[28]	0	cribb2000[Map 2.21]	0	barton1919[8-9]	817	lebar1975[78]	121.2	barton1922[386]	16.7	barton1922[386]	1	hockings1993[99]	2	yumul-et-al-2009[732-733]	2930	luzon2019	104688	luzon2019	1	alarcon-scott1965	1	alarcon-scott1965	1	alarcon-scott1965; barton1919[19]	4		0	worcester1906[827-828]	0	worcester1906[827-828]	1	worcester1906[827]	0	worcester1906[827-828]	1	worcester1906[827]	40000	census-office-of-the-philippine-islands1918[28, 900]; conklin1980[36]	2	hockings1993[99-100]	2	hockings1993[99-100]	1	alarcon-scott1965	5	hockings1993[100]			1	barton1919[19]	4	alarcon-scott1965; barton1922[387]	1	alarcon-scott1965; barton1919[77]	2	dumia1979[7]	1	lebar1975[80]	1	barton1922[398, 421]	1	barton1922[391-392, 394, 397]	1	barton1922[397]	1	barton1922[391-392, 397]	4	barton1922[398]	2	barton1922[396-397]	1	barton1922[396-397]	1	barton1922[396-397]	1	barton1922[398]			0	dumia1979[38-40]	3	kwiatkowski2004[499]; dumia1979[24, 83]	2	dumia1979[24, 38-39]	0	dumia1979[38-40]	0	kwiatkowski2004[498]			3	dumia1979[82]; kwiatkowski2013[371]	2	kwiatkowski2013[267-368]	2	kwiatkowski2004[498]; wardini2008[71-72]	2	kwiatkowski2013[374]	2	dumia1979[43-44, 54]					3	kwiatkowski2013	1	dumia1979[27-28]	2014						1	kwiatkowski2004[499]

Kalinga	"The Kalinga are one of several large, historically non-Christian groups living in the mountains of northern Luzon. They are grouped together on the grounds of cultural and linguistic similarity rather than common identity - according to Lawless (1993), 'Kalinga' was originally an exonym meaning ""enemy"". The principal source on this culture (Dozier, 1966) focuses on the Northern Kalinga, who were less acculturated than the Southern Kalinga at this time."		1916	barton1949[v]; dozier1966	2	barton1949[17-18]; Kaoka	Longgu is the name of a village on the north coast of Guadalcanal, and of the language spoken by people living in this village and its neighbours. The principal source on this culture (Hogbin, 1964) refers to this language as 'Kaoka'. The Longgu-speakers worshipped their ancestors, as well as supernatural agents embodied in sharks and snakes.	long1395	1911	hogbin1964[2, 72-94]; hogbin1964	0	hogbin1964[72-90]	2	hogbin1964[72-73, 78-79]	2	hogbin1964[72-73, 75-76]	1	hogbin1964[72-73, 83-84]	0	hogbin1964[72-92]	1	hogbin1964[72]	0		2	hogbin1964[4]	1	hogbin1964[79-84, 83]	0	hogbin1964[79-84]	1	hogbin1964[4, 72-90]	1	hogbin1964[78]	0	hogbin1964[4-18, 72-90]	1	hogbin1964[13-14]	0	hogbin1964[41-50]	1	hogbin1964[72]	1	hogbin1964[72]; keesing1984[142-143]	0	hogbin1964[72]	1	hogbin1964[72]	1	hogbin1964[72]; keesing1984[142-143]	2	bellwood_1995[109]	1	gratton1991[89]	0	cribb2000[Map 2.21]	1	hogbin1964[47-50]	0	cribb2000[Map 2.23]	0	tryon-hackman-1983[24]	1724	tryon-hackman-1983[24]; daft-logic-distance-calculator2014	160.7	hogbin1964[Map (Guadalcanal and the surrounding Solomon Islands)]; google-mapsnone	-9.7	hogbin1964[Map (Guadalcanal and the surrounding Solomon Islands)]; google-mapsnone	1	hogbin1964[1-2]	2	guadalcanal-island2011	2330	guadalcanal-island2011	5302	guadalcanal-island2011	1	hogbin1964[75, 78]	0	hogbin1964[58-61, 72-90]	2	hogbin1964[6, 73, 79]	3	hogbin1964[77, 79]	0	hogbin1964[1, 19-40, 23]	0	hogbin1964[1, 19-40, 23]	0	hogbin1964[1, 19-40, 23]	2	hogbin1964[23-24]	2	hogbin1964[23-24]	1000	hogbin1964[2, 5]	3	hogbin1964[4-18, 4]	1	hogbin1964[4-18, 4]	3	gratton1991[90]	3	gratton1991[90]			2	hogbin1964[2, 5, 6]	4	hogbin1964[51]	2	hogbin1964[51-61]	2	hogbin1964[59, 61]	0	bellwood-et-al-1975	1	hogbin1964[3]	1	hogbin1964[3]	0	hogbin1964[3, 41-50]	1	hogbin1964[3]	4	hogbin1964[3]	3	hogbin1964[3]	3	hogbin1964[43]	3	hogbin1964[3]	0	hogbin1964[47-50]			0	gratton1991[91]			2	gratton1991[91]									2	hogbin1964[95]			2	hogbin1964[3]							3	hogbin1964[95]			2014

Kayan	The Kayan live along a number of river valleys in northern Borneo, including the Kayan, from which they take their name. Historically, the Kayan were skilled ironworkers, and exported knives and swords to other indigenous peoples of Borneo.	reja1241	1899	hose-mcdougall1912a[v]; rousseau1998[19]	2	hose-mcdougall1912b[4-5]; Kedang	The name 'Kedang' denotes a region on the north coast of the island of Lomblen in Eastern Indonesia, a state that encompassed this area in the past, the language spoken in this area, and the people inhabiting this area. Like a number of other Eastern Indonesian peoples, the Kedang acknowledged a high god whose name, Ula-Lojo, was composed of the words for 'Moon' and 'Sun'. Ula-Lojo was conceived as remote, and more earthly beings known as  'the spirits of the land' were the usual recipients of worship. In the late 19th century, the state of Kedang was conquered by the neighboring state of Adonara and its Dutch allies. Subsequently, most Kedangese converted to Christianity.	keda1252	1909	barnes1974[23-26, 10]	1	barnes1974[89-142, 158-233, 103-124]	2	barnes1974[136]	0	barnes1974[89-142, 158-233]	2	barnes1974[72, 75, 128-129]	2	barnes1974[62-63, 218-219,]	1	barnes1974[63, 215-216, 218-219]	0	barnes1974[28-29]	1	barnes1974[28-29]	1	barnes1974[190, 202]	1	barnes1974[190, 202]	1	barnes1974[89-142, 158-233, 3-4, 33, 58, 40-41, 125-140]	1	barnes1974[105]	0	barnes1974[89-102]	1	barnes1974[218-219]	0				0	blust2007; keesing1984; blevins2008			0	blust2007; keesing1984; blevins2008	0	blust2007; keesing1984; blevins2008	2	bellwood_1995[109]	1	barnes1974[2-3]	1	barnes1974[103-124, 158-217, 174]; cribb2000[109]	1	barnes1974[2-3, 10-12]	1	barnes1974[2-3, 103-224]	0	barnes1993[131]	677	daft-logic-distance-calculator2014; barnes2001[272-273]	123.8	barnes1974[8]; google-mapsnone	-8.2	barnes1974[8]; google-mapsnone	1	barnes2001[272-273]; lomblen-island1998	2	audley-charles1986[243]	1644	lomblen-island1998	1292	lomblen-island1998	1	barnes1974[181-182, 205]	1	barnes1974[12-13, 103-224]; barnes2001[286-287]	3	barnes1974[89-92, 90-95]	2	barnes1993[133]	0	barnes1974[16-19, 143-209, 158]	0	barnes1974[16-17, 143-209]	0	barnes1974[16-19]	0	barnes1974[16-19]	1	barnes1974[143-209, 215]	11000	barnes1974[19]	1	barnes1993[132]	3	barnes1993[132]	3	barnes1993[132]	5	barnes1993[132]			4	barnes1974[10-12, 19]	4	barnes1974[89-102]	3	barnes1974[4-13]	3	barnes1974[4-13]	0	barnes1993[131]	2	barnes1974[16-17]	1	barnes1974[17]	2	barnes1974[16]	2	barnes1974[17]	4	barnes1974[16]	0	barnes1974[16-17]	0	barnes1974[16-17]	0	barnes1974[16-17]	0	barnes1974[11-12, 16-17]			0	barnes1974[10]	3	barnes1993[131]	2	barnes1974[ix, 10]; barnes1974	0	barnes1974[10]	2		1				2	barnes1974[9]; barnes1993[132]	2	oxfam2008[9]	1	barnes1974[11-12]					0	national-geospatial-intelligence-agency2009[158-162]	3	barnes1993[131]	2	barnes1993[131]	2014							
Kei	The Kei Islands are an archipelago in eastern Indonesia whose indigenous people constitute a single ethnolinguistic group. Much of Keiese adat (customary law) is traditionally derived from Bali.	keii1239	1864	hooe-2012[46-53, 98-102]			0	hooe-2012[46]																									1	hooe-2012[74, 212]											2	bellwood_1995[109]	1	hooe-2012[49]	2	hooe-2012[116]	1	hooe-2012[37, 39]	1	hooe-2012[47]	23	hooe-2012[31-32]	351	hooe-2012[31-32]	132.8	hooe-2012[30]; google-mapsnone	-5.8	hooe-2012[30]; google-mapsnone	4	hooe-2012[30]	3	hooe-2012[30]									2	hooe-2012[46-63, 98-102, 112-120]													18000	hooe-2012[45, 48]			3	hooe-2012[68-98]							3	hooe-2012[45, 55-58]									1	hooe-2012[70]			4	hooe-2012[64]			2	hooe-2012[64]	2	hooe-2012[64-78]	2	hooe-2012[64-78]	2	hooe-2012[64-78]	1	hooe-2012[64-78]			0	hooe-2012[46-53]	3	hooe-2012[48]			0	hooe-2012[46-53]	0	hooe-2012[44-46]	2	hooe-2012[35]			2	hooe-2012[41-44]	2	hooe-2012[64]	2	hooe-2012[64-78]					1	kai-islands-2015	3	hooe-2012[37-44]	0	hooe-2012[37-44]	2014		2	hooe-2012[47]	1	hooe-2012[47]	1	hooe-2012[48, 52]
Kelabit	The Kelabit are rice farmers who live high in the mountains of northern Borneo. The Kelabit had little direct contact with peoples other than their direct neighbours until after World War II, but cultural changes as a result of external forces, such as the abandonment of headhunting, may have taken place much earlier.	kela1258	1939	janowski1991[28-41]	3	talla1979[256-300, 260-261]	1	talla1979	2	talla1979[266, 268-270]; Kiribati	The Gilbert Islands, or Kiribati, are a string of atolls in eastern Micronesia. Although the people of these islands shared a common language, there were considerable cultural differences between the islands north and south of the equator, with the former being more hierarchical than the latter. A notable feature of the indigenous Gilbertese religion was the worship of the sun.	gilb1244	1880	dobbin2011[189]; grimble-maude1989[viii-ix]	2	dobbin2011[193]	2	dobbin2011[190-199]	2	grimble-maude1989[20-27]	2	dobbin2011[190-199]; Kwaio	The Kwaio historically lived in small, autonomous groups in the interior of the large island of Malaita. Their religion was heavily based on ancestral deities and their maintenance of moral standards within the community. The Kwaio were notable for their fierce resistance to colonisation and Christianisation, which resulted a punitive expedition being mounted against them in 1927, during which their religious sites were deliberately desecrated. Subsequently, many Kwaio converted to Christianity, although around a third continue to adhere to their indigenous religion to this day.	kwai1243	1890	keesing1982[13-29, 210-218]	0	keesing1982	0	keesing1982	3	keesing1982[30-39]	1	keesing1982[33, 35-37]	1	keesing1982[1-246, 33, 35]	1	keesing1982[31-33, 38-39, 68-73, 86-87, 93, 04, 225-227]	0	keesing1982[42]	1	keesing1982[40-42]	0	keesing1982[104-111]	1	keesing1982[104-110]	0	keesing1982	1	keesing1982[79-80]	1	keesing1982[19-20, 146-147]	1	keesing1982[18-19, 225-227]	1	keesing1982[161]	1	keesing1982[46-47]	0	keesing1982[46-49]	3	keesing1982[10, 46-49]	1	keesing1982[46]	1	keesing1982[46-47]	2	bellwood_1995[109]	1	keesing1982[22]	0	cribb2000[Map 2.21]	1	keesing1982[20]	0	cribb2000[Map 2.23]	0	keesing1982[13]	1790	keesing1982[13]; Kwara'ae	Kwara'ae are a bush tribe in the northern half of Malaita Island, which is within the Solomon Islands. They have largely converted to Chrisitanity after a fair amount of conflict with colonial powers.	kwar1239	1900	burt1994[6, 111]	0	burt1994[51-84]	0	burt1994[51-84]	2	burt1994[51-54, 69-70]	2	burt1994[52-54]	1	burt1994[52]	1	burt1994[56-60]	0	burt1994[21-23]	0	burt1994[21-23]	1	burt1994[52-53, 56-58]	0	burt1994[52-53]	2	burt1994[73]	1	burt1994[54]	1	burt1994[35-37]	1	burt1994[68]	1		0	burt1994[54-55]	0	burt1994[54]	0	burt1994[54-55]	1	burt1994[54-55]	1	burt1994[54-55]	2	bellwood_1995[109]	1	burt1994[85-87, 104]	0	cribb2000[Map 2.21]	1	burt1994[24, 88]	0	cribb2000[Map 2.23]	0	burt1994[15]	1801	burt1994[15]; daft-logic-distance-calculator2014	160.8	burt1994[15]; google-mapsnone	-8.7	burt1994[15]; google-mapsnone	1	burt1994[15]	2	malaita2019	1438	malaita2019	4200	moore2007[214]	0	burt1994[58-59]	0	burt1994[21-84]	2	burt1994[66]	4		2		0		0		0		1		8000	burt1994[16, 24]; eberhard2020	2	keesing1991[161]	3	burt1994[26-27]; keesing1991[161]	2	keesing1991[162]	3	keesing1991[161-162]	5	keesing1991[162]	1	burt1994[66-69]	3	burt1994[44-49]	1	burt1994[44-49]	2	burt1994[21-139]	0	burt1994[98]	1	burt1994[23]	1	burt1994[23-24]	2	burt1994[23-24]	0	burt1994[23-24]	4	burt1994[23]	2	burt1994[24]	0	burt1994[23-24]	1	burt1994[23-24]	3	burt1994[24]			1	burt1994[111]	3	burt1994[12]	2	burt1994[119]	1	burt1994[183-185]	0		2		3	burt1994[206, 240]	2	burt1994[171]	2		1	malaita2019	1		1	malaita2019			3	burt1994[171]	1	burt1994[111]	2014		2		2		1	burt1994[227-228]
Laboya	The Laboya are one of the many ethnic communities (suku in modern Indonesian terminology) inhabiting the western end of the island of Sumba in Eastern Indonesia. The indigenous religion was a form of ancestor worship. The more distant an ancestor was, the more powerful this ancestor was believed to be. The founding ancestors, called marapu as elsewhere in Sumba, were believed to have had godlike powers. More ordinary spirits of the dead were believed to undergo a series of transformations, eventually becoming clouds and rain.	lamb1273	1983	geirnaert-martin1992[xxiii, 5]	2	geirnaert-martin1992[33-43]	1	geirnaert-martin1992[33, 57, 228-400, 280]	2	geirnaert-martin1992[12, 33-86]	1	geirnaert-martin1992[57-86]	0	geirnaert-martin1992[33-86]	1	geirnaert-martin1992[59-65]	0	geirnaert-martin1992[33-86, 280]	2	geirnaert-martin1992[57]	2	geirnaert-martin1992[60-78]	1	geirnaert-martin1992[60-78, 69-70, 76-77]	2	geirnaert-martin1992[33-43]	1	geirnaert-martin1992[63-64, 285]	0	geirnaert-martin1992[16-86, 193-227]	1	geirnaert-martin1992[35, 69-70]	0	geirnaert-martin1992[16-32]			0	blust2007; Lakalai	"The Lakalai are a subgroup of the Nakanai, who live on the north coast of New Britain. The name ""Lakalai"" is sometimes considered patronising, and for this reason, the Lakalai are sometimes known as the West Nakanai - however, ""Lakalai"" is dominant in the literature. Historically, the Lakalai worshipped ancestors and other spirits of the deceased. The most influential of these spirits was Sumua, who lived in the volcano that overlooked Lakalai territory and controlled its forces."	naka1262	1911	valentine1965[162]; jebens2004[119]	1	valentine1965[162-197, 183-184]	1	valentine1965[162-197, 183-184]	2	valentine1965[184-188]	3	valentine1965[171-172]; Land Dayak	The term 'Land Dayak' was coined during the Brooke era to describe certain inland peoples of Sarawak who were not 'Sea Dayaks' (Iban). As applied here, Land Dayak refers to speakers of the 15 (according to Ethnologue) Land Dayak languages. Although most Land Dayaks live in Kalimantan, almost all the available ethnographic information on this group comes from Sarawak. Most of the Land Dayaks in Sarawak belong to the 'Bidayuh' subgroup.	baub1235	1840	low1848; st-john1862; lebar1972[195]	2	low1848[249-251]	2	low1848[251-252]	2	st-john1862[172]; geddes1954[26-27]	2	st-john1862[168]; Lau	The Lau people historically lived on artificial islands made of coral in the Lau lagoon of northern Malaita. The Lau economy centred around resources from the sea, but the Lau also practiced agriculture on land they owned on the mainland. Lau religion centred around on the worship of ancestral beings, some of whom took the form of sharks. In the 1980s, the Lau were the subject of a documentary involving the decline of their indigenous religion due to Christianity and forces of modernity.	lauu1247	1868	ivens1930[9, 64, 71-74]	0	ivens1930[140-141]	0	ivens1930[140-141]	3	ivens1930[129, 132]	2	ivens1930[129, 132]	0	ivens1930[140-141]	1	ivens1930[151]	0	maranda2001[98]	0	maranda2001[98]	1	ivens1930[126, 135-137]	1	ivens1930[126, 135-137]	2	ivens1930[140-148]	1	ivens1930[167]			1	ivens1930[80-81]	1	ivens1930[238]			0	blust2007[418]			0	blust2007[418]; ivens1930[137]	1	blust2007[418]; ivens1930[137]	2	bellwood_1995[109]	0	ivens1930[71-74]	0	cribb2000[Map 2.21]	1	ivens1930[253, 261-262]	0	cribb2000[Map 2.23]	0	moore2017[47]	1815	"ivens1930[48-53, ""Sketch Map of Mala""]; daft-logic-distance-calculator2014"	160.8	"ivens1930[48-53, ""Sketch Map of Mala""]"	-8.3	"ivens1930[48-53, ""Sketch Map of Mala""]"	2	"ivens1930[48-53, ""Sketch Map of Mala""]"	2	malaita2019	1438	malaita2019	4200	moore2007[214]	1	ivens1930[149-161]	0	ivens1930[129-161, 178-201]	2	ivens1930[84]	4		0	ivens1930[125-127]	0	ivens1930[125-127]	1	ivens1930[125-126]	1	ivens1930[126-127]	1	ivens1930[125]	5500	ivens1930[50]	2	ivens1930[80]	3	ivens1930[80, 89]	2	ivens1930[100]	3				2	ivens1930[48-50, 75-92]	3	ivens1930[75-92, 178-201]	3	ivens1930[75-92, 178-201]	2	ivens1930[54, 90-91, 178-201]	0	ivens1930[74]	2	ivens1930[113-117, 243-275]	0	ivens1930[113-117, 243-275]	2	ivens1930[113-117, 243-275, 250]	0	ivens1930[113-117, 243-275]	3	ivens1930[253, 266-273]	3	ivens1930[256-257]	3	ivens1930[253-261]	3	ivens1930[253-261]	3	ivens1930[253, 261-262]	3	1987woodhead	0	1987woodhead	3	1987woodhead; keesing1991[163]											2	ivens1930[45]	2	molea-vuki-2008[30]	2	ivens1930[45-46]			1	solomon-islands-government2001[18-19]	0	solomon-islands-government2001[19]	3	ivens1930[45]			2014						1	1987woodhead; keesing1991[163]
Lifou	"Lifou is one of the Loyalty Islands north of New Caledonia. Information on the indigenous religion of the island comes from missionaries. Lifouan religion was apparently based around ancestral spirits and culture heroes believed to have lived in the distant past. Magic, centred around objects called ""hazes"" was also important."	dehu1237	1841	ray1917; howe1977[35-45]	0	hadfield1920[154]; ray1917	0	hadfield1920[143-167]; ray1917	2	ray1917[154-156]	2	hadfield1920[143-167]; ray1917	2	hadfield1920[143-167]	1	hadfield1920[152-153]	0		2	ray1917	1	ray1917	0	ray1917	2	ray1917; hadfield1920[155-156]	1	ray1917	1	ray1917	1	hadfield1920[201]	1	hadfield1920[65-66]			0	blust2007; keesing1984; blevins2008[255]			0	blust2007; keesing1984; blevins2008[255]	0	blust2007; keesing1984; blevins2008[255]	0	bellwood_1995[109]	1	howe1977[13]	0	cribb2000[Map 2.21]	1	howe1977[6]	0	cribb2000[Map 2.23]	47.6	daft-logic-distance-calculator2014	1515	daft-logic-distance-calculator2014	167.2	google-mapsnone	-21	google-mapsnone	1	ray1917; google-mapsnone	1	howe1977[3]	85	clarke-bedford	1150	clarke-bedford[65]	1	hadfield1920[162]	0	ray1917	2	guiart-1963[351-345]	3		0	ray1917[254]	0	ray1917[254]; hadfield1920[175-222]	1	ray1917[254]; hadfield1920[175-222]	0	ray1917[254]	1	ray1917[254]; hadfield1920[175-222]	6000	howe1977[155-158]	1	howe1977[9-10]	3	howe1977[9-10]	4	ray1917[287]	5	ray1917[286]			3	howe1977[35, 155-158]	3	howe1974	1	ray1917; howe1974	4	ray1917	0	hadfield1920[67-103]	1	ray1917	1	ray1917	2	hadfield1920[48-50]	1	ray1917	4	ray1917	2	ray1917	2	ray1917	2	ray1917	2	hadfield1920[67-103]	1	howe1977[36-45]	0	howe1977[36-45]	3	howe1977[44-45]	1	howe1977[35-45]	0	howe1977[39-45]; keck1998[171-206]	0	haberkorn2008[122]	2	eberhard2020	3	logan-cole2001[40]	2	howe1977[62]	3	ember-ember2001[1583-1589]	2	loyalty-islands2013	2	logan-cole2001[228]	1	stanley2007[874]	1	logan-cole2001[228]	3	howe1977[62]; central-intelligence-agency-new-caledonia2013; shineberg-foster2020	1	howe1977[57-59]	2014		2		1		1	angleviel-levine2008[52]

Manam	Manam is a volcanic island off the north coast of New Guinea. As the island's soil is poor, the people of Manam depend heavily on trade with the mainland. The people of Manam believe (and possibly still believe) that the volcano on their island is inhabited by a culture heroine called Zaria.	mana1295	1933	wedgwood1934a	0	wedgwood1934a; lutkehaus1995[4-7, 9-11, 22-23, 30-34, 40-43, 53-58, 157-159]	0	wedgwood1934a; Manggarai	Manggarai is the name given to a region in western Flores, to the people inhabiting this area, and to their language. Prior to the advent of Christianity, the Manggarai practiced a religion based on ancestral spirits. A supreme being was present in Manggarai religion, but was believed to involve himself in human affairs only rarely.	mang1405	1920	erb1987[x-xii, 39, 123]	1	erb1987[125-126]	1	erb1987[123-263]	1	erb1987[150-151]	3	erb1987[150-151, 180]	2	erb1987[182-188]	1	erb1987[171]	0	erb1987[56-122]	1	erb1987[56-122]	1	erb1987[531-532]	1	erb1987[511-512]	1	erb1987[56-122, 150-151]	1	erb1987[80-81, 154]	0	erb1987[41-52]	1	erb1987[175]	1	erb1987[729]			0	blust2007; keesing1984; blevins2008[260-261]			0	blust2007; keesing1984; blevins2008[260-261]	0	blevins2008; keesing1984; blevins2008[260-261]	2	bellwood_1995[109]	1		1	cribb2000[Map 2.21]; erb1997[48]	1	erb1997[50-51]; erb1987[7]	2	koentjaraningrat1972a[83]; erb1997[49]	0	erb1987[7]	795	erb1997; daft-logic-distance-calculator2014	120.4	erb1987[830]; google-mapsnone	-8.6	erb1987[830]; google-mapsnone	1	erb1987[830]	3	morwood-et-al2009[438]	2400	morwood-et-al2009[438]	13500	morwood-et-al2009[438]	1	erb1987[527-528, 530-531]	0	koentjaraningrat1972a[83]	2	erb1987[41-52]	3	erb1987[41-52]											155000	erb1987[12, 49-50]	1	koentjaraningrat1972a[82]	3	koentjaraningrat1972a[82]	3	koentjaraningrat1972a[82]	3	koentjaraningrat1972a[82]			4	erb1987[12, 30, 49-50]			3	erb1997	2	erb1987[18-41]; erb1997			1	erb1987[6]; koentjaraningrat1972a[81]	3	erb1987[6]	2	erb1987[6]	3	erb1987[6]	4	erb1987[6]; koentjaraningrat1972a[81]	2	erb1987[6]	1	erb1987[6]	2	erb1987[6]	0	erb1987[6-8]			0	kartomi2001[64]	3	allerton2009[273]	2	allerton2009[273]; erb1987[39]	0	allerton2009	1		1		2		2	erb1987[41, 46-47]	2	manggarai2010; kartomi2001[70]	2	manggarai2010	0		0		0		3	koentjaraningrat1972a[81]; erb1987[38-41]	2	erb1987[39, 40]	2014		1		2	allerton2009[277-278]; kartomi2001[68]	1	allerton2009[273]

Manus (Titan)	"Manus is the largest of the Admiralty Islands off the northern coast of New Guinea. However, the name Manus is also an ethnonym given to the speakers of the Titan language, a specific group living on and around the southern coast of the island. To distinguish the Titan-speakers from other peoples of Manus, they are sometimes known as ""Manus True"". Manus religion, which  the worship of spirits of deceased fathers by their sons, was studied in detail by Fortune (1935)."	tita1241	1900	gustafsson1992[11-13]	2	gustafsson1992[31-33]	0	gustafsson1992[18-50]; Māori	Māori are the indigenous people of New Zealand. New Zealand was settled from Eastern Polynesia, probably in the thirteenth century. Mare	Mare is one of the Loyalty Islands north of New Caledonia. What little is known of religion on Mare suggest an ancestor cult. Marquesas	The Marquesas are a group of very rugged volcanic islands in Eastern Polynesia. Rainfall is highly unpredictable in the Marquesas, and as a result famines were common, and were sometimes catastrophic. The most important supernatural agents were deified spirits of deceased chiefs and priests. Human sacrifice played an important role in Marquesan religion - for example, the deification of a deceased leader required ten human sacrifices. The victims of these sacrifices were always captives obtained in war rather than members of the group.	nort2845	1797	handy1923; thomas-1991[188-189]; ferdon1993[xi-xiv]	2	handy1923[244-248]	0	handy1923[244-248]	2	handy1923[244-248]; Marshall Islands	The Marshall Islands is a group of atolls spread over a large area of Micronesia. Marshallese religion involved a multitude of spirits, known collectively as anij, who are difficult to classify.	mars1254	1856	dobbin2011[121-122]; carucci1991[192]	2	dobbin2011[121-138]	0	dobbin2011[121-138]	0	dobbin2011[121-138]	1	dobbin2011[128]	1	dobbin2011[121-138]	1	dobbin2011[133]	2	erdland2010[232-238]	2	erdland2010[232-238]	1	erdland2010[247-251]	0	erdland2010[247-251]	2	dobbin2011[121-138]; Mekeo	The Mekeo are an Austronesian-speaking people living on the mainland of New Guinea, not far from the capital Port Moresby. In terms of indigenous supernatural belief and practices, the emphasis in Mekeo culture was on the magical rather than the religious. Ungaunga (sorcerers) played a major role in maintaining social order.	meke1243	1889	stephen1995[26-2, 57-59]; hauofa1981	0	stephen1995[54]	0	stephen1995[52-57, 54]; hauofa1981[218-288]	0	stephen1995[54]; hauofa1981[221-222]	2	stephen1995[54]; hauofa1981[221-222]	2	stephen1995[53-54]	1	hauofa1981[222]	0		0		0		0		2	stephen1995[3-4, 180]; hauofa1981[222]	1	hauofa1981[220]	1				1	hauofa1971[159]			0	blust2007; keesing1984; blevins2008			0	blust2007; keesing1984; blevins2008	0	blust2007; keesing1984; blevins2008	2	bellwood_1995[109]	1	mosko1991[198]	0	cribb2000[2.21]	1	hauofa1981[16-17]	0	cribb2000[2.23]	0	hauofa1981[16]	488	hauofa1981[29]; daft-logic-distance-calculator2014	146.6	hauofa1981[29]; google-mapsnone	-8.6	hauofa1981[29]; google-mapsnone	1	hauofa1981[12, 29]	4	oconnell-allen2004[835]	4884	new-guinea2019	821400	new-guinea2019	0	hauofa1981[218-288]	0	hauofa1981[41-45, 218-288]	2	hauofa1981[215-288, 297]	3		0		0		2	1913williamson	1	1913williamson	1	1913williamson	4000	hauofa1981[28]; stephen1974[45-46]	1	stephen1995[11]	3	stephen1995[11]	3	mosko1991[199]	3	mosko1991[199]	4	mosko1991[199]	3	hauofa1981[27-31, 42-45]	3	hauofa1981[66]	1	seligman1910[311]; hauofa1981[44]	2	seligman1910[313-314]	0	hauofa1981[8-25]	2	mosko1991[198]; hauofa1971[15]	2	mosko1991[198]; hauofa1981[15]; 1913williamson	1	mosko1991[8, 25]	2	mosko1991[198]; hauofa1981[15]; 1913williamson	4	hauofa1981[12]; mosko1991[198]	1	hauofa1981[8-25]; 1913williamson	2	hauofa1981[8-25]; 1913williamson	2	hauofa1981[8-25]; 1913williamson	2	hauofa1981[16-17]	1	hauofa1971[22]	0	hauofa1971[21-22]	3	stephen1995[57]	2	hauofa1981[21]	1	hauofa1981[23]					3	stephen1995[27, 57]	2	hauofa1981[20-25]; stephen1995[28]; bergendorff2010	2	bergendorff2010[373-374]	2	hauofa1981[16-20]; stephen1995[7]	2	stephen1995[7]	1	hauofa1981[18]	1	stephen1995[7]; national-geospatial-intelligence-agency2009[168]	3	hauofa1981[20-25]	1	hauofa1981[20-25]	2014		2	bergendorff2010[373, 375]			1	bergendorff2010[375]

Merina	The Merina are one of the indigenous peoples of Madagascar, now known as Malagasy. Although Madagascar is geographically far closer to Africa than to Asia, the cultural and genetic origins of the Merina and other Malagasy peoples lie in Indonesia. During the nineteenth century the Merina became the dominant ethnic group in Madagascar, conquering most of the island before being unseated by the French, who invaded the island in 1895.	plat1254	1820	ellis1838A[iii]; Moken	"The Moken, who live in and around the Mergui Archipelago of Burma and Thailand, are one of the ethnic groups of Southeast Asia known as the ""sea gypsies."" Moriori	The Moriori are the indigenous people (Tchakat Henu) of the Chatham Islands. Because of their harsh and isolated environment, in which agriculture was not possible, the Moriori developed a culture-based on hunting and gathering. Their society was egalitarian and peaceful, traits that are rare in most Polynesian cultures. Lethal violence was subject to a religious prohibition, and rarely or never occurred. In 1835 the Chatham Islands were conquered by Māori from mainland New Zealand. As a result of their harsh treatment at the hands of the invaders, the Moriori suffered catastrophic demographic and cultural decline. Today, around 1000 New Zealanders claim Moriori descent, but little remains of Moriori culture.	mori1267	1834	king1989[39-75]	2	shand1911[14]; skinner1923[55]	2	shand1911[14-15, 185, 187]; king1989[35]					2	king1989[33]	1	shand1911[185]	1	shand1911[16-17, 18]	2	shand1911[18]	1	shand1911[184]	2	shand1911[187]	2	shand1911[18-25, 191-206]	1	king1989[211]	1	shand1911[12]			1	sutton1980[84]			0	blevins2008; blust2007; keesing1984			0	blevins2008; blust2007; keesing1984	0	blevins2008; blust2007; keesing1984	0	bellwood_1995[109]	1	king1989[48-51, 57]	0	cribb2000[Map 2.23]	1	king1989[48-51]	0	cribb2000[Map 2.23]	651.3	king1989[17]; daft-logic-distance-calculator2014	2862	king1989[17]; daft-logic-distance-calculator2014	-176.5	king1989[17, 35]; google-mapsnone	-43.8	king1989[17, 35]; google-mapsnone	2	king1989[31]	2	chatham-islands-2018	287	chatham-islands-2018	900	chatham-islands-2018	1	shand1911[14]	0	shand1911[3]; king1989[50]	2	shand1911[12]			0	shand1911[2-3]	0	shand1911[2-3]	0	shand1911[2]	0	shand1911[2-3]	0	shand1911[2-3]	2000	king1989[31]											2	king1989[31]; sutton1980[85]	3	sutton1980[84]; shand1911[3]	4	sutton1980[84-85]; shand1911[3]	4	king1989[48-52]; sutton1980[84-85]			0	king1989	2	sutton1980[80]	2	sutton1980[80, 83]	0	sutton1980[80]; king1989[24]	1	king1989[24, 30-31, 48, 56]; sutton1980[83]	3	sutton1980[80]; king1989[25]	3	sutton1980[80]; king1989[24, 56]; shand1911[5-6]	3	sutton1980[80]; king1989[24]; shand1911[5]	2	sutton1980[85]	1	king1989[73]	0	king1989[73]	3	king1989[73, 105-106]	2	king1989[73]	0	king1989[39-193]	3	king1989[31, 49, 53-75, 93-94, 135-186]; solomon-thorpe2007[251]	3	king1989[135, 156]	3	moran-et-al2021; central-intelligence-agency-new-zealand2014; king1989[109]	2	king1989[66]; wiltshier-cardow2008[266]	3	king1989[123]; dana2003	2	king1989[89-93, 109, 123, 167-168, 178-179]	2	wiltshier-cardow2008[266]	1	dana2003[17-19]	1	dana2003[15]	3	king1989[53-75, 66]	2	king1989[53-75, 64-65]	2014

Motu	The Motu are an Austronesian-speaking people who historically lived in the area that now Port Moresby, the capital of Papua New Guinea. They were heavily involved in trade, and their trading expeditions (hiri) played an important role in their ceremonial life. In historic times, Motu have played a prominent role in Papua New Guinea society and government.	motu1246	1872	groves1991[212, 213]; turner1878	0	turner1878	0		0	groves-2011[153]	3	groves1991[215]; groves-2011[153-154]	2		1	pita-price1975[54]	0		0		1	groves1991[215]	1		0	goddard-van-heekeren2003	1	gwilliam1982[49]	0				1	pita-price1975[54]			0	blust2007; keesing1984; blevins2008			0	blust2007; keesing1984; blevins2008	0	blust2007; keesing1984; blevins2008	2	bellwood_1995[109]	0	groves1991[212]	0	cribb2000[Map 2.21]	1	groves1991[213]	0	cribb2000[Map 2.23]	0	groves1991[212, 213]	495	groves-2011[xxii]; daft-logic-distance-calculator2014	147.1	groves1991; google-mapsnone	-9.5	groves1991[212]; google-mapsnone	1	groves1991[212]	4	oconnell-allen2004[835]	4884	new-guinea2019	821400	new-guinea2019	0		0		1	groves-2011[80-81]	2	groves1991[214, 215]	0	turner1878	0	turner1878	2	turner1878	0	turner1878	1	turner1878	4500	groves1991[213]	2	groves1991[214]	3	groves1991[214]	2	groves1991[214]; turner1878	3	groves1991[214]	4	groves1991[214]	2	groves1991[212-214]	3	groves1991[214-215]	1	groves1991[215]	1	groves1991[215]	0	turner1878	1	turner1878	1	turner1878	3	oram1977[83-84]	1	turner1878	3	groves1991[213]	3	groves1991[213]	3	turner1878; groves-2011[148]	3	turner1878; groves-2011[148]	3	groves1991[213]; turner1878	3		0	goddard-van-heekeren2003[145]	3	groves1991[215]	2	goddard-van-heekeren2003[145]; groves-et-al1958[123]	0	goddard-van-heekeren2003	3	eberhard2020; port-moresby2018; goddard-van-heekeren2003[148-149]	2	goddard-van-heekeren2003[148]	3	gibson2001[158]; goddard-van-heekeren2003[147-148]	2	groves1991[213]	3	groves1991[213]			2	groves1991[213]	2	port-moresby2018	1	port-moresby2018; national-geospatial-intelligence-agency2009[168]	2	groves1991[213]	0	groves1991[213]	2014		1	goddard-van-heekeren2003			1	goddard-van-heekeren2003[145-146, 155]

Nendo	Nendo is the largest of the Santa Cruz islands. The people of Nendo lived in small, autonomous, egalitarian communities. Religion was based on a class of deities called dukna, most of whom were the spirits of culture-hero like beings who lived in the distant past, and some of whom were powerful enough to be considered gods. These beings were embodied in sacred figurines called munga dukna, many of which were collected by missionaries in the early twentieth century.	nang1262	1875	davenport2005[55]	2	davenport2005[16, 35-94]	0	davenport2005[35-54]	0	davenport2005[35-54]	2	davenport2005[35-54]	1	davenport2005[14-15, 35-54]	1	davenport2005[15]	0	davenport2005[55-65]	1	davenport2005[55-65]	0	davenport2005[37-38]	0	davenport2005[37-38]	0	davenport1964[12-13, 35-54, 67-94]	1	davenport2005[4]	1	graeber1912[110-111]	1	acord2009	0	graeber1912[54-143, 110-111]			0	blust2007; Ngaju	Ngaju (meaning 'upstream') is the name given to a group of linguistically and culturally similar peoples inhabiting the upper reaches of several south-flowing rivers in the south of Borneo. In the past they, along with several other peoples of Borneo, were often known as 'Dayaks'. The indigenous Ngaju religion involved a sky god, Hatalla, and an earth goddess, Jata. According to the missionary and anthropologist Hans Scharer, these two gods were manifestations of one supreme 'godhead'. Although most Ngaju have converted to Christianity, the traditional religion survives to an extent in the form of the syncretic religion Kaharingan.	ngaj1237	1932	scharer1963[v]; baier2007	3	scharer1963[6]	0	scharer1963	0	scharer1963	2	scharer1963[142-154]	1	scharer1963	1	scharer1963[99]	0	scharer1963[27-38]	1	scharer1963[22, 39]	0	scharer1963[142-146]; miles1970	2	scharer1963[142-146]; miles1970	2	scharer1963[16, 29-30]	1	scharer1963[99]	1	scharer1963[41]	1	scharer1963[106]	0	scharer1963			0	blust2007; keesing1984; blevins2008[263]			0	blust2007; keesing1934; blevins2008[263]	0	blust2007; keesing1984; blevins2008[263]	2	bellwood_1995[109]	1	scharer1963[2]	2	baier2007; scharer1963[13]	1	scharer1963[2]	2	baier2007	0	knapen2001[87]	950.1	ethnologue-map-of-kalimantan2014; daft-logic-distance-calculator2014	114	knapen2001[87]; google-mapsnone	-1.7	knapen2001[87]; google-mapsnone	1	scharer1963[1]	4	quek-2009[112]	4095	quek-2009[112]	740000	quek-2009[111]	1	scharer1963	0	schiller1997[1-7, 14]; knapen2001[170-171]; scharer1963[83, 87, 140]	2	scharer1963[39-97]	2	scharer1963[39-119, 131-141]; miles1970	2	scharer1963[86-87]	0	scharer1963[85-94]	2	scharer1963[90-91]					50000	scharer1963[2]	2	lebar1972[188]	2	lebar1972[188]	3	miles1970	5	miles1970[308]			2	scharer1963[39-119]; miles1970			4	knapen2001[86-88]	4	knapen2001[86-88]			1	miles1970	1	miles-1976[29-32]; miles1970	2	miles-1976[29-33]	1	miles-1976[29-32]	4	miles1970	1	miles-1976[29-32]	1	miles-1976[29-32]	2	miles-1976[29-32]; miles1970	3	miles-1976[31-32]; miles1970	3	miles-1976[105]; baier2007	1	baier2007	3	schiller1997[23]; baier2007	2	scharer1963[2]	2	baier2007	3	miles-1976[1, 115-117]; schiller1997[23]			3	miles-1976[125]	2	schiller1997[139]			2	scharer1963	1	schiller1997[16]	1	schiller1997[14]	0	schiller1997[14-16]	3	miles-1976[102-124]; schiller1997[132-147]	2	miles-1976[102-124]; schiller1997[132-147]	2014		3	baier2007	3	baier2007	1	schiller1997[23]; scharer1963[3]

Nias	Nias is a large island off the west coast of Sumatra. Despite its long history of interaction with the Islamized peoples of Sumatra, the people of Nias maintained their indigenous religion, as well as their political independence, until the early twentieth century. However, Nias religion has identifiable Hindu elements, presumably dating to the time prior to the Islamization of Indonesia. The high god of Nias was called Lowalangi, and was conceived as a cosmic herdsman who kept human beings as his pigs.	nias1242	1865	hummel-telaumbanua2007[1, 19]; loeb1974-1935-first-published	2	hummel-telaumbanua2007[19-22]	1	hummel-telaumbanua2007[19-25]; Nuaulu	The Nuaulu are subsistence farmers who live on the south coast of the island of Ceram in Eastern Indonesia. They are one of the few peoples in Indonesia who have retained their indigenous religion, which largely involves the worship of ancestral spirits, to the present day.	sout2895	1970	ellen2014[xix]	1	ellen2014[68-72, 72]	0	ellen1986[68-72]	2	ellen2014[22, 68-72]	3	ellen2014[22, 68-72]	1	ellen2014[68-72]	1	ellen2014[69-70]					1	ellen2014[180-182]	1	ellen2014[180-182]	2	ellen2014[68-72]	1	ellen2014[70]									0	blust2007; keesing1984; blevins2008[261]			0	blust2007; keesing1984; blevins2008	0	blust2007; keesing1984; blevins2008[261]	2	bellwood_1995[109]	1	ellen2014[72]	2	cribb2000[Map 2.21]; ellen1983[3-4]	1	ellen2002[294]	2	ellen2002[289]; ellen2014[72]	0	ellen2014[2-3]	918	ellen2014[18]; daft-logic-distance-calculator2014	129	ellen2014[18]; google-mapsnone	-3.2	ellen2014[18]; google-mapsnone	1	ellen2014[xviv]	4	de-jong1998[317-318]	3019	ceram-2013	17148	ceram-2013	1	ellen2014[179]	1	ellen2014[276]; ellen2002	2	ellen2014[42-44, 73]	3	ellen2014[42-44]					0	ellen2014[55, 59, 82, 91, 94, 110, 137, 142]	0	ellen2014[55, 59, 82, 91, 94, 110, 137, 142]			500	ellen2014[19-21]	2	ellen2014[17-25]	3	ellen2014[17-25]							2	ellen2014[17-25, 42-44]			3	ellen2014[21]; ellen2002	3	ellen2014[21]; ellen2002			1	ellen1977[52]	3	ellen1977[52-53]	3	ellen1977[52, 65]	3	ellen1977[52-53]	4	ellen1977[52, 65]	0	ellen1977	2	ellen1977[52-53]	2	ellen1977[52-53]	0	ellen1977			0		1	ellen2014[292]			0	ellen2014[5]			1	eberhard2020	1	ellen2014[21]	2	ellen2014[21]			2	ellen2002[282]	2	ellen2014[21-22]; ellen2002			1	national-geospatial-intelligence-agency2009[166]; ellen2002	1	ellen2014[5, 21]	0		2014						1	ellen2014[26, 292]

Ontong Java	"Ontong Java, also known as Lord Howe Atoll, is a large atoll north of the main Solomon Islands chain. As it is culturally Polynesian but is considered to be geographically outside Polynesia, it is considered one of the ""Polynesian Outliers"". The name ""Ontong Java"", bestowed by Abel Tasman, is misleading - the island is far from (and geographically dissimilar to) Java itself, and the people of Ontong Java share only a distant cultural relationship (by virtue of speaking an Austronesian language) with the Javanese. The atoll is sometimes known as Lord Howe, or as Luangiua, although the latter properly refers to only one of the two islets making up Ontong Java. Ontong Javanese society differed from many other Polynesian societies in having only a weakly developed concept of hereditary rank. Religion in Ontong Java was based on the worship of ancestors - there were apparently no gods."	onto1237	1899	hogbin1934[166, 227]	0	hogbin1930	0	hogbin1930	2	hogbin1930	2	hogbin1930	1	hogbin1930	1	hogbin1934[143-165]	0	hogbin1934[168-172]	0	hogbin1934[168-172]	0	hogbin1934[143-144]	0	hogbin1934[143-144]	0	hogbin1930; Paiwan	The Paiwan inhabit the southern tip of Taiwan. They are known, among other things, for their belligerence towards occupying powers - subjugation of the Paiwan by the Chinese and Japanese was a long and bloody process. Historically, they worshipped a number of supernatural beings, the most important of which were ancestral spirits. Some of these spirits were believed to inhabit sacred knives and swords.	paiw1248	1895	matsuzawa1989[16-35]	2	ferrell1969[44-45]	2	ferrell1969[44-45]	2	lebar1975[133]; mcgovern1922[136]	3	tan2002[170]; Palau	Palau, or Belau, is a group of islands in Micronesia. Missionary efforts to Palau began in the 1890s, and since the mid-twentieth century most Palauans have been Christian. However, elements of the indigenous religion survive in the syncretic religion Modekngei, which arose during, and in opposition to, Japanese rule.	pala1344	1871	dobbin2011[165-166]	2	dobbin2011[169-175]	2	dobbin2011[169-175]	2	dobbin2011[169-175]	2	dobbin2011[169-175]	2	dobbin2011[169-175]	1	dobbin2011[181]	0	dobbin2011[167-169]	1	dobbin2011[166-169]	1	dobbin2011[181-184]	1	dobbin2011[181-184]	1	dobbin2011[166-175]	1	dobbin2011[175, 188]	1	hisakatsu1993[245]	1	hisakatsu1993[245]					0	blevins2008; Rapa Nui	"The Pacific island of Rapanui (Easter Island) represents the easternmost point of known Austronesian settlement. The island is famous for its stone statues (moai), which probably represented founding ancestors or chiefs. It is widely argued that Easter Island had suffered a demographic and cultural collapse several decades prior to European contact. This collapse, sometimes known as the ""1680 event"", has been attributed, most famously by Diamond (2005), to ecological overexploitation. However, the reasons for the event, as well as whether it occurred at all, are controversial."	rapa1244	1862	metraux1940[36-49]	3	metraux1940[309-316, 331-341]; mccall1994[40]	2	metraux1940[316-317]	2	metraux1940[316-317]	1	metraux1940[308-341, 319-320]	2	metraux1940[316-317]	1				1	metraux1940[314]	1	metraux1940[119]	2	metraux1940[119]	2	metraux1940[316-317]	1	metraux1940[310]	1	metraux1940[328]	1		1	metraux1940[328]	2	metraux1940[130-131]			3	metraux1940[120]	1	metraux1940[130, 328]	1	kirch1984[277]; Rarotonga	Rarotonga is a high island in the southern Cook Islands. The islanders converted to Christianity in the 1820s and 1830s, and information on the indigenous religion is fragmentary. We do know that the Rarotongans worshipped some of the great Pan-Polynesian gods such as Rongo and Tangaroa, as well as more local deities such as the deified founding ancestor Tangiia. These gods were represented by enormous wooden images, which were destroyed during the conversion process.	raro1241	1822	baltaxe-1975[98-99]	2	gill1856[13-14]; sissons1989	1		2	sissons1989	1		0		1	gill1856[14, 16]	1	marck1996	0	smith-1898[68]	0	gill1892[11-19]	1	gill1856[14]	2	smith-1898[77-78]	1		1	gilson-crocombe1980[13]	1	gilson-crocombe1980[8-9]	1	gilson-crocombe1980[13-14]	2	gilson-crocombe1980[11-12]	1	gilson-crocombe1980[11-12]	3	gilson-crocombe1980[7-8, 11-12]	1	gilson-crocombe1980[11-12]	1	gilson-crocombe1980[11-12]	0	bellwood_1995[109]	1	gilson-crocombe1980[4]	0	cribb2000[Map 2.21]	2	baltaxe-1975[19-21]	0	cribb2000[Map 2.23]	203.6	daft-logic-distance-calculator2014	4735	daft-logic-distance-calculator2014	-159.8	baltaxe-1975[22];
